At this step, be aware that for parisian gnocchi we use hot dough for a very special reason!
Why is that?
Let me tell you
Parisian gnocchi are somewhat of an oddity in the Western repertoire, in that they're made with a hot water dough—much like Chinese-style dumpling or stretched noodle dough.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Parisian gnocchi are somewhat of an oddity in the Western repertoire, in that they're made with a hot water dough—much like Chinese-style dumpling or stretched noodle dough.

conversation.utterance: With most Western breads and pastries, cold or room temperature liquid is added to flour before kneading it. There are two kinked proteins in flour, glutenin, and gliadin. Get them lubricated and rub them around enough through mechanical action (like kneading), and they tend to stretch out and bind with each other, forming the stretchy protein matrix known as gluten.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: With most Western breads and pastries, cold or room temperature liquid is added to flour before kneading it.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: There are two kinked proteins in flour, glutenin, and gliadin.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Get them lubricated and rub them around enough through mechanical action (like kneading), and they tend to stretch out and bind with each other, forming the stretchy protein matrix known as gluten.

conversation.utterance: I see.
Gluten is what gives dough structure, and the more it's kneaded and worked, the tighter and more elastic it becomes.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Gluten is what gives dough structure, and the more it's kneaded and worked, the tighter and more elastic it becomes.

conversation.utterance: Next

A hot water dough, on the other hand, works differently. By adding flour directly to boiling water, you actually end up not only denaturing the proteins, but smashing them into small pieces. Some degree of gluten can still form, but because cooked proteins aren't nearly as stretchy or clingy as raw ones, you won't get anywhere near the elasticity of a cold-water dough.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: A hot water dough, on the other hand, works differently.

provenance.paragraph_text: Some degree of gluten can still form, but because cooked proteins aren't nearly as stretchy or clingy as raw ones, you won't get anywhere near the elasticity of a cold-water dough.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: I take another cue from Thomas Keller and add a small dollop of Dijon mustard to my dough, as well as chopped herbs.

conversation.utterance: Are you looking for mustard alternatives?
Yes, please.

Hm so Dijon has a strong taste from the liquid they use in it (it's not quite vinegar, not quite wine).  I'd probably try a blend of some other mustard + a little white wine vinegar (not white vinegar; white wine vinegar) or champaigne vinegar or apple cider vinegar.  If you have dry mustard powder, and some time to let it sit, you could also try making your own; maybe that helps to make mustard taste better for you?

provenance.page_title: Is there a substitute for Dijon mustard and if so, what is it?
provenance.paragraph_text: Dijon has a strong taste from the liquid they use in it (it's not quite vinegar, not quite wine).  I'd probably try a blend of some other mustard + a little white wine vinegar (not white vinegar; white wine vinegar) or champaigne vinegar or apple cider vinegar.  (Maybe even a dry white wine, if you have that on hand).If you have dry mustard powder, and some time to let it sit, you could also try making your own; most of the recipes online seem to use a dry white wine as their base, a few use white wine vinegar.

May I ask you: Are you good at mixing a dough by hand?
I am

Ok then you can actually do that by hand. If not, use a stand mixer.  Cooked side-by-side, there's absolutely no detectable difference between the wooden spoon and the stand-mixer method, provided you beat extremely vigorously. If you're even slightly lax with the hand-beating, then the stand mixer method will produce superior results every time.

What's the benefit to leaving the mixture to rest?
Let me see...
This will let it cool down slightly while allowing any vestiges of overworked gluten to relax and any under-hydrated starch to hydrate, helping the gnocchi to puff properly as they poach.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab

At this point, you need to concentrate on piping the gnocchi into the pot.
OK
How many portions am I expecting to make here?
This recipe yields gnocchi for four servings.
OK
Once simmered what do I do?

Once they're poached, you can transfer them to a rimmed baking sheet, toss them in a bit of oil, and let them cool down.  At this stage, they can be transferred to a sealed container and stored in the refrigerator for up to a few days until you're ready to fry or broil them just before serving. Just as with regular pasta, this means that if you make them in advance, dinner is only 20 to 30 minutes away.

conversation.utterance: OK great
When putting them into the water, please make sure you cut off as many as you can in ONE minute.
I have done that. Is this the final part to making the gnocchi?

Not yet, but the goal is to pipe and cut as many gnocchi as you possibly can within about a minute, so that the last gnocchi that drops in won't be too far behind the first one that entered the pool. Once they've finished cooking, you fish them out and start again with the next batch.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Once they've finished cooking, you fish them out and start again with the next batch.

conversation.utterance: As you practice and your speed goes up, you should be able to pipe 30 to 40 gnocchi per minute, which greatly reduces overall prep time.

What is a gnocchi souffle?
Let me see...

For this, add gnocchi in a single layer and toss to coat with browned butter. Cover with cheese, then transfer to broiler. Cook until puffed and golden brown, about 10 minutes. Sprinkle with herbs and serve.

conversation.utterance: Best is to cover them in a blanket of finely grated Parmesan cheese.  After a brief stint under the broiler, they come out puffed and crisp, ready to be served straight out of their skillet.

provenance.page_title: How to Make Parisian Gnocchi | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: I brown just enough butter to give them a nice coating, add the gnocchi and toss to combine, then cover them in a blanket of finely grated Parmesan cheese.
